review.title: Multi-Criteria Optimal Planning for Energy Policies in CLP
review.abstract: In the policy making process a number of disparate and diverse issues such as economic development, environmental aspects, as well as the social acceptance of the policy, need to be considered. A single person might not have all the required expertises, and decision support systems featuring optimization components can help to assess policies. Leveraging on previous work on Strategic Environmental Assessment, we developed a fully-fledged system that is able to provide optimal plans with respect to a given objective, to perform multi-objective optimization and provide sets of Pareto optimal plans, and to visually compare them. Each plan is environmentally assessed and its footprint is evaluated. The heart of the system is an application developed in a popular Constraint Logic Programming system on the Reals sort. It has been equipped with a web service module that can be queried through standard interfaces, and an intuitive graphic user interface.

metadata.title: Multi-Criteria Optimal Planning for Energy Policies in CLP

sections.text: Building on previous work on Strategic Environmental Assessment, we have developed a full-fledged system that is capable of creating optimal plans for a specific goal, performing multi-objective optimizations, providing Pareto with optimal plans and comparing them visually. Each plan is evaluated ecologically and its footprint is evaluated. At the heart of the system is an application developed in a popular Constraint Logic programming system based on the Reals variety. It is equipped with a web service module that can be queried via standard interfaces and an intuitive graphical user interface. KEYWORDS: CLP applications, Strategic Environmental Assessment, Regional Energy Planning

sections.heading: 3.2 Indicators
sections.text: Thanks to the extension presented in Section 3.1, it is possible to quantify the emissions of some gases, metals, etc. Such data can be used to examine plans aimed at minimising them, but it is not clear how the emissions are to be compared. For example, a policy maker might know that NOX is toxic to humans, but what about heavy metal emissions? The European Commission (2006) published a set of indicators that quantify the effects of different substances on human toxicity, global warming and acidification: e.g. Annex 1 contains 100 chemicals with their human toxicity factor, defined as the toxicity of the substance compared to that of lead (Pb). Using the weights in the tables, for example, one can give the total human toxicity (in kg equivalent emitted Pb), global warming (kg equivalent emitted Pb), global warming (kg equivalent of CO2), and global warming (kg equivalent of CO2).

sections.heading: 3.3 Computing the Pareto front
sections.text: The approach outlined in section 2 enables the optimisation of a single function. However, in the case of regional planning, it is very difficult (if not impossible) to design a unique function that includes all the objectives important to the user. Therefore, we have added a further extension towards multi-objective optimisation. In the case of a multi-objective optimisation problem, a solution µ is optimal if it is not possible to improve the result for an objective function without at least degrading another objective function. Specifically, in the case of a multi-objective problem with n functions to be minimised, a solution µ is optimal if there is no other solution µ, so that µj ≤ м j exists for 1 ≤ j ≤ n and there is at least one i, 1 ≤ i ≤ n, so that µi < µ х i. sections.heading: 5 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: The CLP program has been integrated into a standard web service and has an intuitive graphical user interface. The CLP program will be the centerpiece of the platform of the EU-FP7 ePolicy project, which also includes components such as a social simulator, an opinion leader and a mechanism designer, all controlled by the described CLP program. Preparatory work has been carried out to integrate with the mechanism designer (Milano et al. 2012) and a social simulator (Borghesi et al. 2013). Future work will take place on a more detailed level, e.g. taking into account the decommissioning of fixed costs. This work was partially supported by the EU-FP7 funding program No. 287.
